abstract: In considering the role of private insurance companies in Medicare’s future, it is worth noting the political factors that have made private Medicare plans more costly to date, three economists write.
snippet: In considering the role of private insurance companies in Medicare’s future, it is worth noting the political factors that have made private Medicare plans more costly to date, three economists write.
lead_paragraph: Dana P. Goldman is the director of the Leonard D. Schaeffer Center for Health Policy and Economics at the University of Southern California. Adam Leive is a graduate student at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. Daniel McFadden is a senior fellow at the Schaeffer Center and the 2000 Nobel winner in economic science.

headline.main: Why Private Medicare Plans Don’t Cost Less

byline.original: By Dana P. Goldman, Adam Leive and Daniel McFadden

abstract: A check of Citigroup’s board roster, which reportedly clashed with Vikram S. Pandit, reveals a number of former Wall Street executives with lengthy experience in banking. Many of the directors joined the board only in the last four years.
snippet: A check of Citigroup’s board roster, which reportedly clashed with Vikram S. Pandit, reveals a number of former Wall Street executives with lengthy experience in banking. Many of the directors joined the board only in the last four years.
lead_paragraph: Vikram S. Pandit’s sudden exit from Citigroup appears to have much to do with tension with the bank’s board.

headline.main: The People Who Make Up Citi’s Board

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced
